fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is loosely following the material covered in the Math 5 series at California Institute of Technology (based on Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra) or the Math 150 series at University of California, Davis (based on Artin's Algebra).
We have already seen a number of different "species" of Mathematical Gadgets, like:

It turns out, all the information which was really interesting was encoded in the "structure-preserving transformations" between them. (That was the bulk of our time spent studying Elementary linear algebra and Intermediate linear algebra, after all!)
We can form an abstraction describing this situation where we have a [gadget] and [transformations] between them: this is category theory.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

fr:ol.fr:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

fr:li.fr:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

fr:ol.fr:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.

fr:title.text: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The more modern approaches to teaching abstract algebra incorporates some degree of category theory into the mix.

Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter 0 is perhaps the most bold attempt to reorganize abstract algebra around category theory entirely. Instead of ending at Galois theory, Aluffi concludes with homological algebra.
Some ideas from the traditional approach (like "groups with operators") turn out to be confused and muddled (which should be replaced with groups acting on other groups).

If I had to teach abstract algebra to undergraduates, I am torn between the traditional approaches (starting from van der Waerden's Moderne Algebra onwards) which I just outlined, and more modern adaptations which wrap everything in the framework of category theory. Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter Zero seemingly attempts a happy medium, and I am unhappy with it.

One fortunate aspect to Forester is that I'm not forced to choose one or the other. I can outline the "traditional" presentation of topics, and the "modern" presentation of topics, and allow the reader to pick which manner of presentation they wish to peruse.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Well-ordering principle
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every nonempty subset A\subseteq \mathbb {N} has a minimal element:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall A\subseteq \mathbb {N}\ldotp A\neq \emptyset \implies \exists a\in A\ldotp \forall x\in A\ldotp a\leq x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division algorithm
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any integers a,b\in \mathbb {Z}, there exists q,r\in \mathbb {Z} such that 0\leq r<|b| and a=qb+r.
We could take A=\{a-qb\mid q\in \mathbb {Z},a-qb\geq 0\}, then apply the Well-ordering principle to give us r as a minimal element of A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Greatest common divisor
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If a,b\in \mathbb {Z} are nonzero integers, there exists a unique positive integer called the Greatest Common Divisor of a and b, usually denoted \gcd (a,b), such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} a and \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} b (so \gcd (a,b) is a common divisor of a and b)
if e\mathrel {\bigm |} a and e\mathrel {\bigm |} b is another integer, then e\mathrel {\bigm |}\gcd (a,b) (so \gcd (a,b) is the greatest such divisor).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \gcd (a,b)=1 we say a and {b} are Coprime (or are Relatively Prime).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unique prime factorization
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any n\in \mathbb {N}, we may write it as a product n=p_{1}^{\alpha _{1}}(…)p_{k}^{\alpha _{k}} of distinct primes p_{i} and exponents \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb {N}. Here "uniqueness" means if we have another factorization n=q_{1}^{\beta _{1}}(…)q_{\ell }^{\beta _{\ell }}, then k=\ell and we have a bijection \sigma \colon \{1,…,k\}\to \{1,…,\ell \} such that p_{i}=q_{\sigma (i)} and \alpha _{i}=\beta _{\sigma (i)}. In other words, the two factorizations differ only in the ordering of factors.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euler totient
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We have \varphi (n) be the number of positive integers less than n which are coprime to n, \varphi (n)=|\{k\in \mathbb {N}\mid k<n,\gcd (k,n)=1\}|. So \varphi (12)=|\{1,5,7,11\}|=4, but \varphi (11)=10.

fr:title.text: Euler totient is multiplicative on products of coprime numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euler totient is multiplicative on products of coprime numbers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let m,n\in \mathbb {N} be coprime \gcd (m,n)=1. Prove or find a counter-example: \varphi (mn)=\varphi (m)\varphi (n).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a fixed positive integer. Let us define the Equivalence relation on the integers by a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a). This is reflexive (a\sim a since n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-a)), symmetric (a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a)\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-b)\iff b\sim a) and transitive.
Then the quotient set \mathbb {Z} /\mathord {\sim } is often denoted \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z}. Moreover, there are well-defined operations [a]+[b]=[a+b] and [a]\cdot [b]=[a\cdot b].

We have implicitly used binary operators when discussion the algebra of matrices, Fields, Vector Spaces, and so on. Some concrete examples include Matrix Addition, Matrix Subtraction, and Matrix Multiplication.
Unary operators have been infrequently mentioned. For example, the Matrix Transpose is a unary operator on the set of matrices.
Tradition dictates we explicitly formalize the notions of binary and unary operators.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. A Binary Operator (or, more archaically, Law of Composition) is a function \mu \colon X\times X\to X which is various denoted using infixed notation a\star b or a\cdot b or ab (or, if commutative, a+b) for any a,b\in X.

fr:title.text: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set. Then X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) the Set of all functions from A to A has a binary operator, namely Composition of functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Associative if \forall a,b,c\in X\ldotp \mu (a,\mu (b,c))=\mu (\mu (a,b),c)
Examples of associative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that Composing functions is associative.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is associative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} has Matrix Multiplication is Associative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} can be equipped with the Commutator which is a binary operator denoted [A,B]=AB-BA for any n\times n matrices A and B over \mathbb {F}. The commutator is not associative, i.e., in general we have [A, [B, C]] \neq [[A,B],C] but it satisfies a variant called the Jacobi Identity: [A, [B, C]] + [B, [C, A]] + [C, [A, B]] = 0 for any n\times n matrices A, B, and C.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Commutative if \forall a,b\in X\ldotp \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)
Examples of commutative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is commutative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Addition is Commutative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Some non-examples:

fr:ul.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Multiplication is not commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Let e\in X be an element. We say e is a Unit (or identity element) for \mu if \forall a\in X\ldotp \mu (a,e)=a\land \mu (e,a)=a.

fr:title.text: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Examples of identity elements for binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

fr:ul.fr:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that the Identity function is the identity element for the Composition of functions.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then its 0 acts as an identity element for addition and 1 acts as an identity element for multiplication.

Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} we see that Multiplying by Identity Matrix acts like an identity element for matrix multiplication; and also Matrix Addition with Zero Matrix has the zero matrix act like the identity element for matrix addition.

fr:title.text: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Commutator of matrices over a Field \mathbb {F} (or a suitable ring). It turns out, the commutator has no identity element. If it had one, say \mathbf {E}, then for any matrix \mathbf {A} we would have [\mathbf {E},\mathbf {A}]=\mathbf {A} and by anticommutativity of the commutator [\mathbf {A},\mathbf {E}]=-\mathbf {A}. But then we find the Jacobi Identity fails to hold: [\mathbf {E},[\mathbf {B},\mathbf {C}]] + [\mathbf {B}, [\mathbf {C}, \mathbf {E}]] + [\mathbf {C}, [\mathbf {E}, \mathbf {B}]] = [\mathbf {C},\mathbf {B}]\neq 0.

fr:title.text: Identity element is at most unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element is at most unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Then there exists at most 1 Identity element for \mu in X.
If e_{1}\in A and e_{2}\in A are two possible identity elements, then e_{1}=\mu (e_{1},e_{2})=e_{2}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set equipped with a Binary operator \mu with an identity element e\in A, let a\in A. A (Two-Sided) Inverse of a is an element b\in A such that \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)=e.

(1) If \mu is an Associative binary operator, then we can just speak of "inverses" of elements without the "two-sided" prefix. This is because the Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique
(2) If there are multiple binary operators on A, then we should specify that b is an inverse of a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let \mu be an Associative binary operator on A. Let e\in A be the Identity element for \mu . For any element a\in A, there is at most 1 inverse for a with respect to \mu .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Group consists of a set G equipped with an Associative binary operator \star and an Identity element with respect to \star , usually denoted either e\in G or 1\in G, such that every element has a unique inverse, \forall a\in G\ldotp \exists a^{-1}\in A\ldotp a\star a^{-1}=a^{-1}\star a=e.
(1) When the binary operator for the group is commutative, we usually use + for the binary operator and 0 for the identity element.

(2) The "exact formalization" varies. For example, we could have equipped G with a binary operator \star , a unary operator (-)^{-1}\colon G\to G, and a constant element e\in G; this is what we will find useful in category theory later. But they are describing "the same thing". So don't worry about it if you're reading a textbook with a slightly different definition.

(3) The intuition is that G consists of bijections from a set to itself, and the binary operator is just the Composition of functions and the identity element is just the Identity function. These bijections are "symmetries" of the set.
(4) See also Forrester-Barker's Group objects and internal categories for a way to generalize the notion of groups to other settings.

The whole motivation for a group is to describe symmetries, which was usually described using a Left group action. The first application was to study the symmetries of polynomials in an attempt to find roots of polynomials, which culminated in Galois theory.
When we define a Group (or Vector Space or...), we typically have a kind of "template" for the definition which looks like:

html:blockquote.fr:p: A Gadget consists of some stuff (sets or other gadgets like fields) equipped with some structure (functions, subsets, subset families like topologies, or specific elements) such that a bunch of properties (usually equations) hold.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: John Baez and James Dolan were the first to explore this template for definitions. See also Sections 2.4 and 3.1 of Baez and Shulman.

Model theorists typically describe this as a tuple (all the "stuff" and "structure" are crammed together into one tuple) which satisfy some axioms (the "properties"). While this is neat, it lacks some of the desired "inheritance" (like a Field really is an Abelian group with addition, extended with a multiplication operator and a "one" element). Computer Scientists would suggest using a "finite map" instead of a tuple.

There is also some tension between "Mathematical Practice" and what is desirable when formalizing concepts in a proof assistant. For example, we would often want to define a group as a group object internal to the category of sets, but that adds a lot of needless complications to formalizing this in a proof assistant (where we would want as Spartan a structure as possible).

fr:title.text: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then \mathbb {F} equipped with its addition operation forms a group where the identity element is the zero \in \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Integers form a group under addition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers form a group under addition

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The integers \mathbb {Z} form a group when equipped with addition. The identity element is 0\in \mathbb {Z}. This is another commutative group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. A Permutation \pi of n elements is a bijection from the set \{1,2,…,n\} to itself.
Let X be a set. A Permutation of X is a Bijective function f\colon X\to X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric Group of degree n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Symmetric Group of degree n to be the set S_{n} of all permutations of n elements equipped with Composition of functions since composing two permutations of n elements is another permutation of n elements.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's not hard to prove this, indeed, forms a Group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric group of a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Symmetric Group of X to be the Group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) consisting of all permutations on X, equipped with Composition of functions as its Binary operator.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quaternion Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may define the Quaternion Group as consisting of the set Q_{8}=\{-1\}\cup \{i^{m}j^{n}k^{p}\mid 0\leq m,n,p\leq 3\} where we identify 1=i^{0}j^{0}k^{0} and it obeys the identities i^{2}=j^{2}=k^{2}=ijk=-1 and so we write -i=i^{3}, -j=j^{3}, and -k=k^{3}, and also (-1)^{2}=1. We have (-1)i=-i, (-1)j=-j, and (-1)k=-k. After a bit of work, we find ij=-ji=k jk=-kj=i ki=-ik=j

Let A be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator with Identity element e\in A. We define the Set of all invertible elements in A to be the set of all elements with a (two-sided) inverse, A^{\times }=\{a\in A\mid \exists a^{-1}\in A\ldotp \mu (a,a^{-1})=\mu (a^{-1},a)=e\}.

fr:title.text: Set of invertible elements for associative binary operator is a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of invertible elements for associative binary operator is a group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set equipped with an Associative binary operator \mu with an Identity element e\in A. Then the Set of all invertible elements equipped with \mu forms a Group.
We need to show that A^{\times } is closed with respect to \mu , i.e., for any a,b\in A^{\times }, we have \mu (a,b)\in A and also e\in A^{\times }.
Well, we see \mu (e,e)=e which implies e^{-1}=e and therefore e\in A^{\times }.

Let a,b\in A^{\times }. Then we claim \mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}) is the inverse element for \mu (a,b), since \begin {align}\mu (\mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}),\mu (a,b)) &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (a^{-1},\mu (a,b)))\hbox { by associativity}\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (\mu (a^{-1},a),b))\hbox { by associativity}\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (e,b))\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},b)=e,\end {align} and similar reasoning shows \mu (\mu (a,b), \mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}))=e. Hence multiplying two elements of A^{\times } together yields another element in A^{\times }. So we have a group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear Group of matrices
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be defined more generally replacing \mathbb {F} with a unital (possibly noncommutative) ring R, or even a ringoid (where we don't require additive inverses to exist).

fr:title.text: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Let V be a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. We define the General Linear Group on V to be the group \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V) consisting of all invertible linear maps from V to itself, equipped with composition and the identity linear transformation as the identity element.

When we pick an ordered basis B for V and write matrix M(g) relative to B for each linear transformation g\in \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V), then we recover the General Linear Group of matrices over \mathbb {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dihedral group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Dihedral group D_{n} to consist of the set \{x^{k}y^{j}\mid 0\leq k<n,0\leq j\leq 1\} where we also write x^{0}y^{0}=1, such that x^{n}=y^{2}=1 and also yx=x^{-1}y. It's not hard to see yx^{k}=x^{-k}y by applying that second relation k times.
(1) The dihedral group describes the symmetries of the regular n-gon in the plane, where x is rotation anticlockwise by 2\pi / n and y is reflection about a line through the origin.
(2) Some authors (like Dummit and Foote) call this group D_{2n} because it is of order 2n.
(3) D_{1} has x=1 and D_{0} is degenerate.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: "Abstract" groups and "group of transformations"
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I, Section 6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Some older books distinguish 'abstract groups' from 'groups of transformations'. This distinction appears in van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I, Section 6, if not earlier.
Briefly, an 'abstract group' is presented in terms of 'generators' and 'relations'. For example, we did this implicitly when discussing the Quaternion Group and the Dihedral group.

A 'group of transformations' is an automorphism group of a Mathematical object. For example, the General Linear group of a vector space describes the automorphism group of a vector space, the Permutation of a set describes the automorphism group of a set. This is a bit anachronistic as a description, since van der Waerden thought of a group of transformations as "just" bijections of some set.
We should think of an "abstract group" as "just meaningless symbols satisfying some equations", but a "group of transformations" are "concrete realizations" of symmetries "in the wild".
When a Group has a commutative binary operator, we call it an Abelian group (or a Commutative group).
Typically, for Abelian groups, we write the binary operator as addition, and the identity element as 0.

I have grown to believe over the years that an Abelian group should be reserved for a generalization of a Vector Space if we just forget about scalar multiplication and the field. This is how most proof assistants handle it.
Commutative groups are groups which are, well, equipped with a Commutative binary operator.

Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let n\in \mathbb {N}_{0} be a non-negative integer. We write g^{n} and define it inductively by g^{0}=e and g^{n+1}=g\star g^{n}. We can extend this to integer exponents by defining g^{-n}=(g^{-1})^{n}.
Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let m,n\in \mathbb {Z}. Then g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n}.
By induction on n.
Base case: n=0. We see g^{m}g^{0}=g^{m}e=g^{m}=g^{m+n}.

Inductive case: Assume the inductive hypothesis g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n} for arbitrary n\in \mathbb {Z}. We want to show g^{m}g^{n+1}=g^{m+n+1} and also g^{m}g^{n-1}=g^{m+n-1}, but this follows by the inductive hypothesis and associativity.
Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let m,n\in \mathbb {Z} be integers. Then (g^{m})^{n}=g^{mn}.
Divide this up into the four cases where m\geq 0 or -m>0 (i.e,, m<0), and separately n\geq 0 or -n>0 (i.e., n<0). It's useful to note g^{-m}=(g^{-1})^{m}=(g^{m})^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Cyclic subgroup generated by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic subgroup generated by an element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and let g\in G. Then we define the Cyclic subgroup generated by g to be the commutative group \langle g\rangle whose underlying set is \{g^{n}\mid n\in \mathbb {Z}\}.
We need to prove this is actually a group and it is commutative.

Claim 1: it is a group. Suffices to show the binary operator of G is closed on this set and e\in G and it contains all its inverses. The binary operator of G is clearly closed on this set by the Product law and g^{0}=e so the identity element belongs to it. Further, if g^{n}\in \langle g\rangle , then its inverse g^{-n}\in \langle g\rangle clearly belongs to it. Hence this is really a group.
Claim 2: it is commutative. We see for any arbitrary g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n}=g^{n+m}=g^{n}g^{m} by the Product law and the commutativity of addition for integers.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Order of a group element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G. We define Order of g is the integer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) equal to either the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} such that g^{n}=e or if no such positive integer exists, it is defined to be zero.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Some authors prefer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) to be infinite if there is no smallest positive integer n such that g^{n}=e, but it can complicate some results.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. We define the Order of G to be \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (G)=|G| the cardinality of the underlying set of elements of G.
If the underlying set of elements of G is not finite, then we typically just assign \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (G)=\infty .

fr:title.text: Order of group element is order of subgroup generated by that element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Order of group element is order of subgroup generated by that element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and g\in G. Then the order of g is the order of the subgroup generated by g, i.e., \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)=\mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (\langle g\rangle ).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cancellation law
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 1.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let G be a Group, let a,b,c\in G. Then the following all hold:
If ac=bc, then a=b; and
If ca=cb, then a=b.

(1) Assume ac=bc, then multiply both sides on the right by c^{-1}, we see the left-hand side becomes (ac)c^{-1}=a(cc^{-1})=ae=a by assocativity and inverse, and the right-hand side becomes (bc)c^{-1}=b(cc^{-1})=be=b. Hence a=b.
(2) Assume ca=cb. Multiply both sides on the left by c^{-1} gives the result by similar reasoning as (1).

fr:title.text: Criteria for a group element being its own inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a group element being its own inverse

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let g\in G. Then g^{2}=e if and only if g^{-1}=g.

fr:title.text: Inverse of subset of a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of subset of a group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. We define the Inverse of A to be the subset A^{-1} of G equal to A^{-1}=\{a^{-1}\in G\mid a\in A\}.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets of a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets of a group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let A and B be subsets of G. We define their Product to be the subset AB of G equal to AB=\{ab\in G\mid a\in A,b\in B\}.
(1) This definition can be generalized to any nonempty multiplicative magma.
(2) There is no standard term for this product. Historically, van der Waerden called it the "complex product" (or "products of complexes"). Others have called it the Frobenius product.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is nonempty iff subsets are nonempty

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is nonempty iff subsets are nonempty

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. Then AB
eq \emptyset if and only if A
eq \emptyset and B
eq \emptyset .
(Equivalently, AB=\emptyset if and only if either A=\emptyset or B=\emptyset .)

fr:title.text: Product of subsets of a group is associative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets of a group is associative

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B, C be subsets of G. Then A(BC)=(AB)C.

fr:title.text: Inverse of products of subsets is reverse product of inverses

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of products of subsets is reverse product of inverses

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A and B be subsets of G. Then (AB)^{-1}=B^{-1}A^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is distributive over union

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is distributive over union

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B and C be subsets of G. Then A(B\cup C)=(AB)\cup (AC) and (A\cup B)C=(AC)\cup (BC).

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is distributive over intersection

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is distributive over intersection

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B and C be subsets of G. Then A(B\cap C)=(AB)\cap (AC) and (A\cap B)C=(AC)\cap (BC).

fr:title.text: Multiplying a subset of a group by a group element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplying a subset of a group by a group element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G be an element of G. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G.

fr:ol.fr:li: We define gA to be the subset of G equal to gA:=\{g\}A
We define Ag to be the subset of G equal to Ag:=A\{g\}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Equivalently, x\in gA iff there is an a\in A such that x=ga; and x\in Ag iff there is an a\in A such that x=ag.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. A Subgroup of G is a group H such that its underlying set of elements is a subset of the set of elements of G, and the binary operator of H is the same as the binary operator of G restricted to H.
When H is a subgroup of G, we write H\leq G.
When H\neq G, we say H is a Proper Subgroup of G and write H\mathrel {<} G.
Let G be a Group. The Improper Subgroup of G is the subgroup H=G.
Some older texts distinguish "the improper subgroup of G" from "the group G" by writing \Omega _{G} for the improper subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 2.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let H\neq \emptyset be a nonempty subset of G. If for any x,y\in H we have xy^{-1}\in H, then H forms a Subgroup.
Furthermore, if H is finite, then it suffices to check that H is closed under multiplication (i.e., for any x,y\in H we have xy\in H).
If x=y, then xx^{-1}=e\in H contains the identity element.
For any x\in H, we have ex^{-1}=x^{-1}\in H, so H is closed under inverting elements.
For any x,y\in H, we have y^{-1}\in H, so x(y^{-1})^{-1}=xy\in H, which means H is closed under its binary operator.
Hence altogether H forms a subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1} and H_{2} be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} and H_{2} have the same set of elements, then H_{1}=H_{2}.
Let G be a group. Then the Trivial Subgroup of G is the subgroup \mathbf {1}_{G} consisting of only the identity element: for any x, we have x\in \mathbf {1}_{G} if and only if x=e.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Torsion subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 2.1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be an Abelian group. We define the Torsion Subgroup of G to be the Subgroup H=\{g\in G\mid \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)<\infty \}.
Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G and K\leq G be Subgroups of G. Then the intersection H\cap K is a [strict] subgroup of G.
We can check H\cap K=K\cap H.
Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G, H_{2}\leq G, and H_{3}\leq G be Subgroups of G. Then (H_{1}\cap H_{2})\cap H_{3}=H_{1}\cap (H_{2}\cap H_{3}).

fr:title.text: Intersection of a family of subgroups is a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of a family of subgroups is a subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let \mathcal {F} be a family of Subgroups of G. Then \bigcap \mathcal {F} is a subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Product of subgroups with subsets of the group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subgroups with subsets of the group

fr:title.text: Associativity of product of subsets and subgroups

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associativity of product of subsets and subgroups

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G and K\leq G be Subgroups of G. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. Let U_{K}\subseteq G be the set of elements of K. Then the following all hold:

fr:title.text: Product of subgroups with group elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subgroups with group elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let g\in G be an element of G. Let U_{H}\subseteq G be a subset of G equal to the set of all elements of H. Then we define:

fr:title.text: Associativity of product of subgroups with group elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associativity of product of subgroups with group elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let g\in G and h\in G be elements of G. Then the following all hold:

fr:title.text: Distributivity of multiplying subgroups with group elements over intersecting subgroups

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Distributivity of multiplying subgroups with group elements over intersecting subgroups

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G, let a\in G be an element of G. Then the following all hold:
Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Left Cosets of H to be the family of subsets of G equal to \{gH\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.
Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Right Cosets of H to be the family of subsets of G equal to \{Hg\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.
Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Index of H to be the Cardinal number [G : H] equal to the cardinality of the left cosets of H.
(1) This is also equal to the cardinality of the right cosets of H.
(2) When G is a finite group, this is a natural number. More generally, when there are only finitely many left cosets of H, the index of H is a natural number.
Let G be a finite Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Then the product of index of H with the cardinality of H equals to cardinality |G|=[G : H]|H|.

Let G be a Group, let S\subseteq G be a subset of elements of G. Then we define the Subgroup Generated by S to be the subgroup \langle S\rangle such that S\subseteq \langle S\rangle and for any subgroup H\leq G such that S\subseteq H we have \langle S\rangle \leq H.

fr:title.text: Subgroup generated by a set is smallest subgroup containing that set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup generated by a set is smallest subgroup containing that set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let S\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then \langle S\rangle =\bigcap \{H\leq G\mid S\subseteq H\}.

fr:title.text: Subgroup generated by empty set is trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup generated by empty set is trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let S\subseteq G be empty S=\emptyset . Then the subgroup generated by S is \langle S\rangle =\langle \emptyset \rangle =\mathbf {1}_{G} the Trivial Subgroup of G.

Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. We define the Frobenius Product of H_{1} with H_{2} to be the subset H_{1}H_{2} of G equal to H_{1}H_{2}=\{h_{1}h_{2}\in G\mid h_{1}\in H_{1}, h_{2}\in H_{2}\}. We stress this is not a subgroup.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This operator usually doesn't have a standard name. The only place I have seen it called "the Frobenius product" is in Adolfo Ballester-Bolinches, Ramon Esteban-Romero, and Mohamed Asaad's Products of Finite Groups (Walter de Gruyter, 2010, pg 1). In van der Waerden's Algebra, this was called the "product of complexes" or "complex product" (terminology which Kurzweil and Stellmacher use in their Finite Group Theory on page 6 of the English edition, right before proposition 1.1.5).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Then the Lattice of Subgroups of G consists of all possible Subgroups of G, whose join is given by H\vee K=\langle HK\rangle the subgroup generated by the Frobenius product, and whose meet is given by H\wedge K=H\cap K the intersection of subgroups (which is a subgroup).

fr:title.text: Conjugation of an element by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of an element by an element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a and b be elements of G. The Conjugate of a by b is the element a^{b}:=b^{-1}ab of G.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b,g\in G be elements of G. If a^{g}=b^{g}, then a=b.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of identity element is identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of identity element is identity element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G be an element of G. Then 1_{G}^{g}=1_{G}.

fr:title.text: Any element which is a conjugate of the identity must be the identity

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any element which is a conjugate of the identity must be the identity

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. If a^{b}=1_{G}, then a=1_{G}.

fr:title.text: Conjugating an element with respect to identity element is the given element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugating an element with respect to identity element is the given element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Then a^{1_{G}}=a.

fr:title.text: Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Then a^{a}=a.

fr:title.text: Composing conjugation is conjugation of products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing conjugation is conjugation of products

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,g,h\in G be elements of G. Then (a^{g})^{h}=a^{gh}.

fr:title.text: Conjugate of power is power of conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugate of power is power of conjugate

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. Let n\in \mathbb {Z} be an integer. Then (a^{n})^{b}=(a^{b})^{n}.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. We say a is conjugate to b if there exists an element g\in G such that a=b^{g}.

fr:title.text: Any element is conjugate to itself

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any element is conjugate to itself

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be any element of G. Then a is conjugate to a.
This follows from Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G. If a is conjugate to to b, then b is conjugate to a.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b,c\in G. If a is conjugate to to b, and if b is conjugate to c, then a is conjugate to c.

Taking Conjugation is a transitive relation together with Any element is conjugate to itself and Conjugation is a symmetric relation means that the predicate "is conjugate to" forms an Equivalence relation.
Consequently, we will be able to say "a and b are conjugate" instead of caring especially about the ordering of arguments to the predicate.

fr:title.text: Conjugacy classes are either disjoint or equal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugacy classes are either disjoint or equal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Hence the sets \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (a) and \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (b) are equal.
Let G be a Group. We define the set of Conjugacy Classes of G to be the set \{\mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (g)\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of subset by a subset

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of subset by a subset

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. We define A^{B}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid a\in A,b\in B\} to be the Conjugate of A by B.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of a subset by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of a subset by an element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Let b\in G be an element of G. We define A^{b}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid a\in A\} to be the Conjugate of A by b.
Equivalently, using Conjugation of subset by a subset, we see A^{b}=A^{\{b\}}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of an element by a subset

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of an element by a subset

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Let B\subseteq G be a subset of G. We define a^{B}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid b\in B\} to be the Conjugate of a by B.
Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. We define the predicate A is conjugate to B to mean there exists a g\in G such that A=B^{g}.

fr:title.text: Any subset is conjugate to itself

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any subset is conjugate to itself

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then A is conjugate to itself.

fr:title.text: Conjugate subsets forms a symmetric relation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugate subsets forms a symmetric relation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. If A is conjugate to B, then B is conjugate to A.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This means we can speak of "A and B are conjugate" or mix up the ordering of arguments in this predicate freely and wildly.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G, B\subseteq G, and C\subseteq G be subsets of G. If A is conjugate to B, and if B is conjugate to C, then A is conjugate to C.

Let G be a Group, let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then we define the Conjugacy Class of A to be the family of subsets \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (A) of G equal to \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (A):=\{A^{g}\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of a subgroup by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of a subgroup by an element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Let g\in G be an element of G. Then we define the Conjugation of H by g to be the subgroup H^{g} of G such that its underlying set is given by the conjugation of the subset by g; i.e., for any a\in G, we have a\in H^{g} if and only if there is an h\in H such that a=h^{g}.
Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. We define the predicate H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2} to mean there exists a g\in G such that H_{1}=H_{2}^{g}.
Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup. Then H is conjugate to H.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2}, then H_{2} is conjugate to H_{1}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We will now be able to say "H_{1} and H_{2} are conjugate" or mix up the arguments willy-nilly.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G, H_{2}\leq G, and H_{3}\leq G be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2}, and if H_{2} is conjugate to H_{3}, then H_{1} is conjugate to H_{3}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This means that, along with Conjugation is a reflexive relation and Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation, conjugation of subgroups forms an Equivalence relation.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Conjugacy Class of H to be the collection \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (H) of subsets of G such that: for any object x, we have x\in \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (H) if and only if there exists a subgroup K\leq G such that x=K and H is conjugate to K.
We should prove this is a well-defined notion.

Existence: The collection of subgroups may be formed by looking at the elements of \mathcal {P}(G) which may be given a subgroup structure. We may then use Set builder notation to form the conjugacy class of H.
Uniqueness: immediate.
Let G be a Group. Let N\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We say N is Normal if for each g\in G we have N=N^{g}.
If further N\neq G, we say N is a Proper Normal subgroup of G.
We will write N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G to indicate N is a normal subgroup of G, and N\mathrel {\triangleleft } G to indicate N is a proper normal subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Every group has a normal subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every group has a normal subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Then \mathbf {1}_{G} is a Normal subgroup of G (thus allowing us to use "normal" as an adjective).

We want to prove: for any g\in G we have \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g}=\mathbf {1}_{G}. Let g\in G. Then for any x\in \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g} we see x=1_{G}^{g}=1_{G}. Hence x\in \mathbf {1}_{G}. Hence \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g}=\mathbf {1}_{G}.

fr:title.text: Intersection of normal subgroups is normal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of normal subgroups is normal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let N_{1}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G and N_{2}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be Normal subgroups of G. Then N_{1}\cap N_{2} is a normal subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Every subgroup of a commutative group is normal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every subgroup of a commutative group is normal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Abelian group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Then H is a Normal subgroup of G.
Since G is commutative, g^{h}=g for all g,h\in G. Then H^{g}=\{h^{g}=h\mid g\in G\}=H. Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. For any a\in G, we have aN=Na.

fr:title.text: Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. Then any left coset of N is also a right coset of N. That is to say, we may just speak of "cosets of N" since all left cosets are right cosets of N.
Immediately follows from Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Centralizer of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let A be a subset of G. Then the Centralizer of A is the subgroup C_{G}(A)=\{g\in G\mid \forall a\in A\ldotp gag^{-1}=a\} consisting of all elements of G which commutes with every element of A.

Let G be a Group, let a\in G be an element of the group. We define the Centralizer of a to be the Subgroup C_{G}(a) of G whose underlying set equals C_{G}(a)=\{g\in G\mid ag=ga\}. Observe this is the same thing as C_{G}(a)=C_{G}(\{a\}) the centralizer of the singleton \{a\}.
Let G be a Group.

fr:ol.fr:li: Let a\in G be an element, let B\subseteq G be a subset. We say a Centralizes B if for each b\in B we have ab=ba. In other words, a\in C_{G}(B) is an element of the centralizer of B.
Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets. We say A Centralizes B if every element a\in A centralizes B; i.e., A\subseteq C_{G}(B) is a subset of the centralizer of B.
Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let B\subseteq G be a subset. We say H Centralizes B if every h\in H centralizes B. In other words, H\leq C_{G}(B) is a subgroup of the centralizer of B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the preceding three definitions, we may replace B with a subgroup K\leq G or an element b\in G.

Let G be a Group. We define the Center of G to be the Subgroup Z(G) of G consisting of all elements which commute with all of G: for any z\in G, we have z\in Z(G) if and only if for every g\in G we have zg=gz.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could define this more generally for any nonempty multiplicative magma, in which case it would be a submagma.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Existence: We see that 1_{G}\in Z(G) since 1_{G}g=g=g1_{G}.
We also see for any x,y\in Z(G) and any g\in G we have (xy)g=x(yg)=x(gy)=(xg)y=(gx)y=g(xy) which means Z(G) is closed under multiplication.
We also see for any x\in Z(G) and g\in G that x^{-1}g=((x^{-1}g)^{-1})^{-1}=(g^{-1}x)^{-1}=(xg^{-1})^{-1}=gx^{-1} which implies x^{-1}\in Z(G).
Hence Z(G) has a group structure induced from G.
Uniqueness: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other.
Let G be any Group. Then its center Z(G) is a Normal subgroup of G.
Let z\in Z(G) and g\in G. Then z^{g}=g^{-1}zg=zg^{-1}g=z which implies Z(G) is a normal subgroup.
Let G be any Group. Then its center Z(G) is a commutative Subgroup of G.
Let x,y\in Z(G). Then xy=yx since every element of the center commutes with any element of the group. Hence Z(G) is commutative.
Similarly, for any elemen g\in G, we can define the Normalizer of g to be N_{G}(g):=N_{G}(\{g\}) the normalizer of the singleton \{g\}.
And if H\leq G is a Subgroup, then we define the Normalizer of H to be the subgroup N_{G}(H) which is just the normalizer of the underlying set of H.
Let G be a Group. Let B\subseteq G be a subset of G.

fr:ol.fr:li: Let a\in G be an element. We say a Normalizes B if a^{-1}Ba=B; in other words a\in N_{G}(B).
Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. We say A Normalizes B if every element of A normalizes B.
Let H\leq G be a subgroup of G. We say H Normalizes B if every element of H normalizes B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can replace B with a subgroup K\leq G and the definition of "normalizes" generalizes accordingly; and we can replace B with an element b, and the definition "normalizes b" is just a synonym for "normalizes \{b\}".

fr:title.text: Normal subgroups have their normalizer be the entire group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Normal subgroups have their normalizer be the entire group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a [strict] Group, let H\leq G be a [strict] Subgroup of G. Then H is a Normal subgroup of G if and only if its Normalizer N_{G}(H)=G.

fr:title.text: Product of elements in a nonempty magma

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of elements in a nonempty magma

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be a nonempty multiplicative magma (i.e., a set equipped with a multiplication operator with no properties imposed). Let (a_{i})_{i=1,…,n} be a finite sequence of elements of M. We define the Product of (a_{i}) to be the element \prod ^{1}_{i=1}a_{i}=a_{1} and for any k+1\leq n+1 \prod ^{k+1}_{i=1}a_{i}=\left (\prod ^{k}_{i=1}a_{i}\right )a_{k+1}. So generically \prod ^{n+1}_{i=1}a_{i}=((((a_{1}a_{2})a_{3})…)a_{n})a_{n+1}.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. We define their Commutator to be the element [a,b] of G equal to [a,b]:=a^{-1}b^{-1}ab.
Caution: Many group theorists prefer defining the commutator [a,b]=aba^{-1}b^{-1} which is more useful in Lie groups.

Let G be a Group. We define the Commutator Subgroup (or Derived Subgroup) of G to be the subgroup G' of G such that G'=\langle \{[a,b]\in G\mid a,b\in G\}\rangle . In other words, it is the subgroup generated by the set of all commutators of all elements of G.
Other notation for this subgroup includes [G,G].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a function. We say \varphi is a Group Morphism (or just Morphism) if it preserves multiplication, i.e., for any g_{1},g_{2}\in G we have \varphi (g_{1}g_{2})=\varphi (g_{1})\varphi (g_{2}).
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N}. The determinant \det \colon \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F})\to \mathbb {F}^{\times } is a Group Morphism.
This follows from Properties of the determinant, specifically property (8), and elements of \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) have nonzero determinant.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This generalizes to any commutative unital ring or even ringoid instead of \mathbb {F}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. If 1_{G} is the identity element of G and 1_{H} is the identity element of H, then \varphi (1_{G})=1_{H}.

fr:title.text: Group morphism preserves inverse of element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group morphism preserves inverse of element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. Let 1_{G} be the identity element of G and let 1_{H} be the identity element of H. If g\in G is any element of G, then \varphi (g^{-1})=\varphi (g)^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Composing group morphisms yields a group morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing group morphisms yields a group morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G_{1}, G_{2}, and G_{3} be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} and \psi \colon G_{2}\to G_{3} be Group Morphisms. Then their composition \psi \circ \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{3} is a group morphism.

Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the subgroup \ker (\varphi ) of G such that its underlying set equals \{g\in G\mid \varphi (g)=e\}.
Existence: We see that \ker (\varphi ) is closed under multiplication since for any x,y\in \ker (\varphi ) has \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)=ee=e which means xy\in \ker (\varphi ).
We also see that for any x\in \ker (\varphi ) that \varphi (x)=e=e^{-1}=\varphi (x)^{-1}=\varphi (x^{-1}) which means x^{-1}\in \ker (\varphi ). So \ker (\varphi ) is closed under inverting elements.
Hence \ker (\varphi ) is a group and its underlying set is a subset of G.
Uniqueness: by Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other.

Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We define the Image of \varphi to be the subgroup \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) of H equal to \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi )=\varphi (G).

fr:title.text: Image of subgroup under morphism is a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Image of subgroup under morphism is a subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G_{1}, G_{2} be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Group Morphism. Let H\leq G_{1} be a Subgroup of G_{1}. Then \varphi (H)\leq G_{2} the image of H under \varphi is a subgroup of G_{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Isomorphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We say \varphi is a Group Isomorphism (or just Isomorphism) if it is bijective and has an inverse function which is a also a group morphism.
When G=H, we say \varphi is a Automorphism of G.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. We typically say G and H are Isomorphic if there exists a Group Isomorphism between them. This is reflexive since the identity function is an automorphism.

fr:title.text: Quaternion group isomorphic to subgroup of {{GL}}_{2}({C})

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quaternion group isomorphic to subgroup of \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits _{2}(\mathbb {C})

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The isomorphism is given by sending A\mapsto j and B\mapsto k, then AB\mapsto i.
Let G and H be two Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. If \varphi is bijective, then \varphi is an isomorphism.

Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. We define the Quotient Group G/N to consist of left cosets of N and the binary operator is given by (gN)(hN)=(gh)N for any g,h\in G. The inverse element of gN is g^{-1}N.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is well-defined because Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. We define the Natural Morphism of N to be the surjective group morphism n_{N}\colon N\to G/N sending g\in N to gN.

The three (sometimes four) isomorphism theorems are important, but no one agrees with how to enumerate them: the first isomorphism theorem is usually the same, but all bets are off for the remaining isomorphism theorems.
These isomorphism theorems may be traced back to Emmy Noether's Abstrakter Aufbau der Idealtheorie in algebraischen Zahl- und Funktionenkörpern (1927).

Let G_{1} and G_{2} be Groups, let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Group Morphism. Then there exists an isomorphism \psi \colon G_{1}/\ker (\varphi )\to G_{2} such that \psi \circ n_{\ker (\varphi )}=\varphi .

Let G be a Group. Let B\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. If M\leq B is a subgroup of B, then we will denote (M)_{B} for M\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } B as a normal subgroup of B.

Let G be a Group. Let B\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a [strict] Normal subgroup of G. Then \frac {\langle BN\rangle }{(N)_{\langle BN\rangle }}\cong \frac {B}{B\cap N}.

Let G be a Group. Let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. Let M\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G and J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be [strict] Normal subgroups of G. If J = N/(M)_{N} and M\leq N, then \frac {G/M}{J}\cong G/N.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. We define the Product Group G\times H whose underlying set is the Cartesian product of two sets of the sets underlying G and H, whose binary operator is given by (g_{1},h_{1})(g_{2},h_{2})=(g_{1}g_{2},h_{1}h_{2}) and the identity element is 1_{G\times H}=(1_{G},1_{H}).

fr:title.text: Product of quotient group with denominator is not isomorphic to the given group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of quotient group with denominator is not isomorphic to the given group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {Z}_{4} be the set of integers modulo 4. This is a commutative group. Let \mathbb {Z}_{2} be the set of integers modulo 2. This is a subgroup of \mathbb {Z}_{4} (just look at the subgroup generated by [2]).

Then the quotient group \mathbb {Z}_{4} / \mathbb {Z}_{2}\cong \mathbb {Z}_{2} is isomorphic to \mathbb {Z}_{2}. But (\mathbb {Z}_{4} / \mathbb {Z}_{2})\times \mathbb {Z}_{2}\not \cong \mathbb {Z}_{4}.

Let \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} be an indexed family of groups. For any group G and for any family of Group Morphisms \varphi _{i}\colon G\to F_{i}, there exists a unique morphism \varphi \colon G\to \prod \mathcal {F} such that for each i\in I we have \pi _{i}\circ \varphi =\varphi _{i} where \pi _{i}(x)=x_{i} is the projection onto the i^{\text {th}} factor of the product group \pi _{i}\colon \prod \mathcal {F}\to F_{i}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This reflects how morphisms contain all the interesting information about constructions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let I\subseteq \mathbb {N} be I=\{1,…,n\}. Let \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} be an indexed family of subgroups of G. If for each i\in I we have F_{i}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G is a Normal subgroup of G, and if and the Frobenius Product of Subgroups F_{1}F_{2}(…)F_{n}=G as sets, and if for each j\in I we have F_{1}(…)F_{j-1}\cap F_{j}=\emptyset , then F_{1}\times …\times F_{n}\cong G.
In this situation, we typically call G the Internal Direct Product of \mathcal {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 5.1.17

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. We say G is Simple if the only normal subgroups of G are \mathbf {1}_{G} and G itself.
In other words, G is simple if and only if the only proper normal subgroup of G is trivial.

Let G be a Group. A Composition Series of G is a finite sequence H_{i} of subgroups of G such that \mathbf {1}_{G}=H_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{n}=G, where H_{i}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{i+1} for each i=0,…,n-1, and in particular H_{i+1}/H_{i} is Simple.
Note: There is no requirement that H_{i} is a normal subgroup of G except for when i=n-1.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For any group G, either there exists a nontrivial proper Normal subgroup N\mathrel {\triangleleft } G or it doesn't. If it does, then we can ask about the Quotient Group G/N and N. If G/N is simple, then we turn our attention to proper normal subgroups of N. We can repeat this questioning, and this gives us a composition series for G as a way of "breaking up" G.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. If \mathbf {1}_{G}=H_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{n}=G, and \mathbf {1}_{G}=K_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } K_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } K_{m}=G, are two Composition Seriess for G, then m=n and there exists a permutation \pi \in S_{n} such that H_{j+1} / H_{j}\cong K_{\sigma (j) + 1} / K_{\sigma (j)}.
In other words, the Composition Series for a group is unique.
Proof by induction on \min (m,n).
Base case: if \min (m,n)=1, then G is Simple, hence any other composition series is of length 1 and the unique subquotient is G.
Inductive argument: This is rather lengthy, I'll return to it.
Let G be a Group, let X be a set. A Left Action of G on X is a function \alpha \colon G\times X\to X such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Identity: for all x\in X, \alpha (1_{G},x)=x; and
Compatibility: for all g,h\in G and for all x\in X, \alpha (g,\alpha (h,x))=\alpha (gh,x)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note: usually we write g\cdot x instead of \alpha (g,x) when the action is unambiguous.

(1) We have a more general notion of an "action" of a group on an object depend on the kind of morphisms on the object. For example, a group acting on a vector space will have g\cdot - be a linear transformation of the vector space when we fix g\in G.

(2) We have a closely related notion of a "representation" of a group. Historically this emerged in a confused and haphazard way, describing several variations like a Permutation representation or a linear representation. Category theory clarified this as an object X and a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (X). This may be viewed as a "curried" form of a group action.
Let G be a Group, let X be a set. A Right Action of G on X is a function \alpha \colon X\times G\to X such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Identity: for all x\in X, \alpha (x,1_{G})=x; and
Compatibility: for all g,h\in G and for all x\in X, \alpha (\alpha (x,g),h)=\alpha (x,gh)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note: usually we write x\cdot g instead of \alpha (x,g) when the action is unambiguous.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If \alpha is a right action of G on X, then we may construct a left action \lambda of G on X by \lambda (g,x)=\alpha (x,g^{-1}). The identity property holds. The compatibility property: \begin {align*}\lambda (g,\lambda (h,x)) &=\alpha (\alpha (x,h^{-1}),g^{-1})\\ &=\alpha (x,h^{-1}g^{-1})\\ &=\alpha (x,(gh)^{-1})\\ &=\lambda (gh,x)\end {align*} as desired. For this reason, it suffices to study the left action of a group.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a group. We define the Automorphism Group of G to be the [strict] group \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (G) consisting of all automorphisms of G and the binary operator is composition.

fr:title.text: Action of a group on another group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Action of a group on another group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Sections 1.7 and 2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and K be Groups. An (Left) Action of G on K is an uncurried form of the group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K); i.e., it's a morphism \alpha \colon G\times K\to K such that \alpha (g,k)=\rho (g)(k).
Usually we write g\cdot k instead of \alpha (g,k) for the left action of G on K, where g\in G and k\in K.
(1) This may be viewed as a special case of a Left group action.
(2) The \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K) group morphism is called a Representation of G on the group K.

Let H and K be Groups. Let \varphi \colon K\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (H) be a group morphism. Then we define the Semidirect product of H with K with respect to \varphi to be the [strict] group H\rtimes _{\varphi }K consisting of all ordered pairs (h,k) where h\in H and k\in K and (h,k)(h',k')=(h\cdot \varphi (k)h',kk') is its binary operator.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The exact ordering of components of the ordered pair (h,k) doesn't matter; we could have (k,h) instead. The important thing is being consistent. The notation for (k,h) is usually K\ltimes _{\varphi }H.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given: H and K be Groups.
We can study this further using group chomology (specifically the first group cohomology H^{1}(K,-)).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The terminology over the years here is rather confused, unfortunately. But it seems the way to think of it is that G is an extension of K by H. It is becoming more common to choose \widehat {K} instead of G for the extension of K.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If further \varphi is an isomorphism, then this describes an isomorphism of group extensions.
If \widehat {G} is not split, then we say it is a "nonsplit extension" of G.

Let p\in \mathbb {N} be a prime number. We see the extension of commutative groups, 0\to p\mathbb {Z} / p^{2}\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / p^{2}\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z}\to 0, is the example of a nonspit extension.

fr:title.text: Criteria for an extension to be split

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for an extension to be split

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \widehat {G} be an extension of G by H. Then \widehat {G} is split if and only if
there is a subgroup K\leq \widehat {G} such that \pi |_{K}\colon K\to G is an isomorphism; or
there exists a set of coset representatives \widehat {G}/H which is a subgroup; or
there is a subgroup K\leq \widehat {G} such that HK=\widehat {G} and H\cap K=\mathbf {1}_{G}; or
\widehat {G} is isomorphic to (as an extension) the semidirect product H\rtimes _{\varphi }G

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation representation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let G be a Group. A Permutation Representation of G on X is a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) from G to the symmetric group of X.
When g\in G and x\in X, we write g\cdot x instead of \rho (g)(x). If there's ambiguity, we'll write \rho _{g}(x) to stress which representation we're using.

More generally, a Permutation Representation of G (without any mention of the representation space X) consists of a set X equipped with a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a "curried" form of a Left group action.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let x\in X. The Orbit of x is the subset G\cdot x of X equal to G\cdot x:=\{g\cdot x\in X\mid g\in G\}.

In physics, we describe the possible states for a given physical system using a configuration space. Symmetries occur to partition the configuration space into orbits, which describe "physically indistinguishable states". This intuition (an orbit describes "redundant states") is a great way to think of orbits of a group action.

Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. We say G acts Transitively (or that it's a Transitive Action) if there is only one Orbit of the action, i.e., for any x,y\in X there exists a g\in G such that g\cdot x=y.
Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let Y\subseteq X. We say Y is an Invariant Subset of X if G\cdot Y\subseteq Y, i.e., for each y\in Y and g\in G we have g\cdot y\in Y.
If there is some ambiguity about which group Y is invariant with respect to, we say Y is G-Invariant (or Stable under G or G-Stable).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This should evoke vague memories from intermediate linear algebra about Invariant subspaces.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let x\in X. The Stabilizer of x is the Subgroup (not necessarily normal) G_{x} of G equal to G_{x}:=\{g\in G\mid g\cdot x=x\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orbit-Stabilizer theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and X be a nonempty set. Suppose G acts on X. Then for each x\in X, the cardinality of the Orbit G\cdot x is equal to the index of the Stabilizer of x, [G : G_{x}]=|G\cdot x|.

fr:title.text: Cosets of stabilizer are bijective with the orbits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cosets of stabilizer are bijective with the orbits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We need to show \overline {f} is a well-defined Function. We see if aG_{x}=bG_{x}, then a^{-1}b\in G_{x} and by definition of the Stabilizer we see a^{-1}b\cdot x=x and therefore a\cdot x=b\cdot x. Therefore this is a well-defined function.
Reading this argument backwards, we establish \overline {f} is injective.
Since \overline {f} maps gG_{x} to g\cdot x, and g\cdot x can be an arbitrary element of G\cdot x, this means \overline {f} is surjective. Hence \overline {f} is bijective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cayley's theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Then there is some symmetric group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (G) and some subgroup H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits {G} such that G\cong H.
Moreover, if the order of G is n, then G is isomorphic to a subgroup of S_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation action
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. The Conjugation Action is an action of G on itself given by g\cdot x:=g^{-1}xg conjugation.

fr:title.text: Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Consider the Conjugation action of G on itself. Let g\in G. Then the centralizer C_{G}(g) of g is the set of all fixed-points of g under this action.
Let h\in C_{G}(g), then hg=gh and so g=h^{-1}gh=g^{h}. This means h is a fixed-point of g\cdot -. This argument holds backwards, which establishes the bijection.

fr:title.text: Index of centralizer is size of conjugacy class

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Index of centralizer is size of conjugacy class

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Consider the Conjugation action of G on itself. Let g\in G. Then the index of the centralizer C_{G}(g) of g is the cardinality of the Conjugacy class of an element of g: [G : C_{G}(g)]=|\mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (g)|.
This follows immediately from Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Class equation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 4.3.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a finite Group. Then |G| = |Z(G)| + \sum _{x}[G : C_{G}(x)] where the sum is taken over representatives from the representatives from distinct conjugacy classes disjoint from the center of G.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Nothing in the proof required G being specifically finite, but we end up with a decomposition of infinite cardinal numbers in the infinite G case...which is not as useful...

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p be a prime number. Let G be a Group. We say G is a p-Group if there is some n\in \mathbb {N} such that |G|=p^{n}.
Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime, G be a Group. If |G|=p^{\nu } for some \nu \in \mathbb {N}, then |Z(G)|>1.

If |Z(G)|=1, then we need p\mathrel {\bigm |}[G : C_{G}(x)] for each coset representative x in each orbit, but this would require p\mathrel {\bigm |}|G|-|Z(G)|, i.e., p\mathrel {\bigm |} p^{\nu }-1 which contradicts our assumption.
Let G be a finite Group. If there exists a prime p\in \mathbb {N} and some r\in \mathbb {N} such that p^{r}\mathrel {\bigm |} |G|, then there exists a subgroup H\leq G such that |H|=p^{r}.
Let G be a finite Group. Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. If p\mathrel {\bigm |}|G|, then there exists an element g\in G such that \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)=p.
Let G be a Group. Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. Let P be a p-subgroup of G. We say P is a Sylow p-Subgroup of G if p\nmid [G : P] (p does not divide [G : P]).

The Sylow theorems tell us about the existence and (non)uniqueness of Sylow p-subgroups of a finite group. The numbering differs book to book, so we will be following I. Martin Isaacs's Finite Group Theory in describing these theorems.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of a Sylow p-Subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.7 (Sylow E-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a finite Group. Let p be a prime number. Then G has a Sylow p-subgroup.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This may be viewed as a partial converse of Lagrange's theorem.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (Wielendt) Let |G|=p^{a}m where a\geq 0 and p\nmid m. Let \Omega =\{A\subseteq G\mid |A|=p^{a}\}. We see that G acts on \Omega by right multiplication. Since this is an action, \Omega is partitioned into orbits, and so |\Omega | is the sum of the orbit sizes.
But |\Omega |=\binom {p^{a}m}{p^{a}}\equiv m\not \equiv 0\pmod {p}, and so |\Omega | is not divisible by p. Then there exists some orbit \mathcal {O} such that |\mathcal {O}| is not divisible by p.

Let X\in \mathcal {O} and H=G_{X} be the Stabilizer of X in G. Then |\mathcal {O}|=|G|/|H| by the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem, and since p does not divide |\mathcal {O}| but p^{a} divides |G|, we must conclude p^{a} divides |H|, and in particular p^{a}\leq |H|.
Since H stabilizes X under right multiplication, we see if x\in X then xH\subseteq X, and then |H|=|xH|\leq |X|=p^{a}.
Since p^{a}\leq |H|\leq p^{a}, we must have |H|=p^{a}, and this is a Sylow subgroup of G as desired.

fr:title.text: Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.11

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let P be an arbitrary p-subgroup of a finite Group G, let S be any Sylow p-subgroup of G. Then there exists a g\in G such that P\subseteq S^{g}.

Let \Omega =\{Sx\mid x\in G\} be the set of right cosets of S in G. Observe |\Omega |=[G : S] is not divisible by p since S is a Sylow p-subgroup of G. We know G acts by right multiplication on \Omega , and so P acts too, and \Omega is partitioned into P-orbits. Since |\Omega is not divisible by p, there must exist some P-orbit \mathcal {O} such that |\mathcal {O}| is not divisible by p.

By the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem, |\mathcal {O}| is the index in P of some subgroup. It follows that |\mathcal {O}| divides |P|, which is a power of p. Then |\mathcal {O}| is both a power of p and not divisible by p, so the only possibility is |\mathcal {O}|=1. Since the members of \Omega are right cosets of S in G, we can consider g\in G such that \mathcal {O}=\{Sg\}.
Since Sg is alone in a P-orbit, it follows that it is fixed under the action of P, so Sgu=Sg for all u\in P. Then gu\in Sg, hence u\in g^{-1}Sg=S^{g}. Hence P\subseteq S^{g}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sylow p-Subgroups are conjugate
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.12 (Sylow C-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S and T be Sylow p-subgroups of a finite Group G, then there exists a g\in G such that T=S^{g}.

This follows immediately from Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup taking P=T gives us T\subseteq S^{g} for some g. Since both S and T are Sylow p-subgroups, we have |S|=|T|=|S^{g}| we have T=S^{g} as desired.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This may be viewed as a "finite analog" of a result in Lie theory where all maximal tori are conjugate to each other.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sylow "Development" Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.14 (Sylow D-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let P be a p-Subgroup of a finite Group G. Then P is contained in some Sylow p-subgroup of G.
In other words, Sylow subgroups are "maximal" among the p-subgroups of G.
Let S be a Sylow subgroup, by Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup there is a g\in G such that P\leq S^{g}. Since |S|=|S^{g}|, S^{g} is another Sylow p-Subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Concluding remarks about introductory group theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Concluding remarks about introductory group theory

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Most "traditional" presentations of abstract algebra end their discussion about groups with the Sylow theorems.

It's difficult for me to present group theory this way, because group theory goes hand-in-hand with the representation of groups. But I promised to discuss the "traditional" treatment of group theory. Promises made, promises kept.

fr:title.text: Prefatory comments about traditional introduction to rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prefatory comments about traditional introduction to rings

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is roughly the content of the Math 5B course at California Institute of Technology, organized from my notes from the course offered Winter Quarter 2018. These notes about rings would constitute the first half of the course (literally, the first 13.5 lectures out of the 27 lectures).

Most courses about rings are the same, but vary in level of rigor and detail. UC Davis's Math 150B course was not quite at this level of maturity, but it was close. But it is nowhere near the level of sophistication of UC Davis's graduate abstract algebra course content.

A (Unital) Ring consists of a set R equipped with
an Abelian group structure (R,+,0), and
a multiplication \star \colon R\times R\to R, and
(Optional) a "one" element 1\in R such that for any a,b,c\in R,
Associativity of addition: a+(b+c)=(a+b)+c
Additive identity element: a+0=0+a=a
Additive inverse: a+(-a)=0
Commutativity of addition: a+b=b+a
(Optional) Associativity of multiplication: a\star (b\star c)=(a\star b)\star c
(Optional) Unital property (i.e., multiplicative identity element): a\star 1=1\star a=a
Left distributivity of multiplication over addition: a\star (b+c)=(a\star b)+(a\star c)
Right distributivity of multiplication over addition (a+b)\star c=(a\star c)+(b\star c) Some rings don't have a multiplicative unit 1, in which case they are "nonunital rings". If we don't care about the existence of the multiplicative unit, we'll just speak of "rings".
